de.esoco.lib.expression

Class Functions

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.expression.Functions

  • public class Functions
extends java.lang.Object
    Contains factory methods to create standard functions.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.Runnable NO_OPERATION
      A runnable instance that does nothing.

      • chain

        public static <I,V,O> Function<I,O> chain(Function<V,O> rOuter,
                                          Function<I,? extends V> rInner)
        Chains two functions together. The output value that is created by evaluating an input value with the inner function will be evaluated by the outer function and the result will be returned. This is equivalent to return rOuter.evaluate(rInner.evaluate(rInputValue)). The generic parameter 'V' designates the intermediate value that is exchanged between the two functions.
        Parameters:
        rOuter - The outer function
        rInner - The inner function
        Returns:
        A new instance of FunctionChain

      • chain

        public static <L,R,V,W,O> BinaryFunction<L,R,O> chain(BinaryFunction<V,W,O> rOuter,
                                                      Function<L,? extends V> rLeft,
                                                      Function<R,? extends W> rRight)
        Chains a binary functions together with two other functions. The output values that are created by evaluating the left and right input values with the left and right functions will be evaluated by the binary outer function and the result will be returned. This is equivalent to return rOuter.evaluate(rLeft.evaluate(rLeftValue), rRight.evaluate(rRightValue)). The generic parameters 'V' and 'W' designate the intermediate values that are exchanged between the functions.
        Parameters:
        rOuter - The binary outer function
        rLeft - The function to evaluate the left input value with
        rRight - The function to evaluate the right input value with
        Returns:
        A new instance of FunctionChain

      • chainLeft

        public static <L,R,V,O> BinaryFunction<L,R,O> chainLeft(BinaryFunction<V,R,O> rOuter,
                                                        BinaryFunction<L,R,? extends V> rInner)
        Chains two binary functions together on their left value so that the left value of the outer function is generated by the inner function and the right value is forwarded unmodified.
        Parameters:
        rOuter - The outer function
        rInner - The inner function
        Returns:
        A new binary function chain

      • chainRight

        public static <L,R,V,O> BinaryFunction<L,R,O> chainRight(BinaryFunction<L,V,O> rOuter,
                                                         BinaryFunction<L,R,? extends V> rInner)
        Chains two binary functions together on their right value so that the right value of the outer function is generated by the inner function and the left value is forwarded unmodified.
        Parameters:
        rOuter - The outer function
        rInner - The inner function
        Returns:
        A new binary function chain

      • coerce

        public static <I,O> Function<I,O> coerce(Function<?,?> fFunction)
        Coerces a function instance to certain generic parameters. This method should be used with caution and only under special circumstances, e.g. for the parsing of functions without evaluation.
        Parameters:
        fFunction - The function to coerce
        Returns:
        The function coerced to the given generic parameters

        Returns a new comparator instance that applies a function to input objects to determine the actual comparable values. NULL results of the compare function are supported.
        Parameters:
        fGetComparable - The function to be applied to input objects to obtain the comparable values
        Returns:
        A new Comparator instance

      • doAll

        @SafeVarargs
public static <I> Function<I,I> doAll(java.util.function.Consumer<? super I> fFirst,
                                                    java.util.function.Consumer<? super I>... rAdditionalFunctions)
        Returns a single function that applies several consumers successively to input values in the order in which they appear in the argument list. The return value of the resulting function will be the input value to support function chaining.
        Parameters:
        fFirst - The first consumer to apply to input values
        rAdditionalFunctions - Additional consumer to apply to input values
        Returns:
        A new function that evaluates all argument functions

      • doAll

        @SafeVarargs
public static <L,R> BinaryFunction<L,R,L> doAll(R rRightValue,
                                                              BinaryFunction<? super L,? super R,?> fFirst,
                                                              BinaryFunction<? super L,? super R,?> fSecond,
                                                              BinaryFunction<? super L,? super R,?>... rFunctions)
        Returns a single binary function that will apply several binary functions successively to left and right input values in the order in which they appear in the argument function list. The return value will be the left-side input value to support function chaining.
        Parameters:
        rRightValue - The default right-side value for unary function invocations
        fFirst - The first function to apply to input values
        fSecond - The second function to apply to input values
        rFunctions - The binary functions to apply to input values
        Returns:
        The unchanged left-side input value

      • doIf

        public static <I,O> ConditionalFunction<I,O> doIf(Predicate<? super I> rPredicate,
                                                  Function<? super I,O> rFunction)
        Returns a new conditional function that will evaluate input values with a certain function if a predicate for this value yields TRUE. If the predicate yields FALSE no function will be evaluated. Conditional functions that also handle a predicate result of FALSE can be created either by invoking doIfElse(Predicate, Function, Function) or by invoking ConditionalFunction.elseDo(Function) on the returned conditional function. The latter variant will create one intermediate function and should therefore not be used in time-critical code.
        Parameters:
        rPredicate - The predicate to evaluate
        rFunction - The function to evaluate input values with if the predicate yields TRUE
        Returns:
        A new function for the conditional evaluation of a function

      • doIf

        public static <I> java.util.function.Consumer<I> doIf(Predicate<? super I> rPredicate,
                                                      java.util.function.Consumer<? super I> fConsumer)
        A variant of doIf(Predicate, Function) for consumers.
        See Also:
        doIf(Predicate, Function)

      • doIfElse

        public static <I,O> Function<I,O> doIfElse(Predicate<? super I> rPredicate,
                                           Function<? super I,? extends O> fIf,
                                           Function<? super I,? extends O> fElse)
        Returns a new function that will evaluate an input value with a certain function if the result of a predicate for this value is TRUE. If the predicate is FALSE another function will be evaluated instead. Provides a more readable way to create instances of ConditionalFunction.
        Parameters:
        rPredicate - The predicate to evaluate
        fIf - The function to evaluate input values with if the predicate yields TRUE
        fElse - The function to evaluate input values with if the predicate yields FALSE
        Returns:
        A new function for the conditional evaluation of functions

      • doIfElse

        public static <I> java.util.function.Consumer<I> doIfElse(Predicate<? super I> rPredicate,
                                                          java.util.function.Consumer<? super I> fIf,
                                                          java.util.function.Consumer<? super I> fElse)
        A variant of doIfElse(Predicate, Function, Function) for consumers.
        See Also:
        doIfElse(Predicate, Function, Function)

      • error

        public static <I,O> BinaryFunction<I,java.lang.String,O> error(java.lang.String sMessage,
                                                               java.lang.Class<? extends java.lang.Exception> rExceptionClass)
        Returns a new binary function instance that throws a certain exception when it's invoked. The exception's error message will be created by invoking String.format(String, Object...) with the given message string and the function's input value as the arguments. As the method Function.evaluate(Object) cannot throw checked exceptions the created exception will be wrapped in an instance of the special runtime exception class FunctionException.
        Parameters:
        sMessage - The error message with optional format elements
        rExceptionClass - The class of the exception to throw
        Returns:
        A new function instance

      • firstInChain

        public static Function<?,?> firstInChain(Function<?,?> rFunction)
        A helper method that returns the function in a FunctionChain that will be invoked first. It is found by recursively traversing the tree of functions by means of the method FunctionChain.getInner().
        Parameters:
        rFunction - The function to start searching at
        Returns:
        The first invoked function in a chain
        See Also:
        lastInChain(Function)

      • invert

        public static <I,O> InvertibleFunction<O,I> invert(InvertibleFunction<I,O> rFunction)
        Returns a new invertible function instance that is the inversion of another invertible function. That means the input parameter becomes the output parameter and vice versa.
        Parameters:
        rFunction - The function to invert
        Returns:
        A new invertible function instance

        Returns:
        The first invoked function in a chain

      • sleep

        public static <T extends java.lang.Number> Function<T,T> sleep()
        Returns a function that invokes Thread.sleep(long) with the time in milliseconds that it receives as the input value. The input value of the function will be returned unchanged to allow function chaining.
        Returns:
        A function constant that causes the current thread to sleep

      • swapParams

        public static <L,R,O> BinaryFunction<R,L,O> swapParams(BinaryFunction<L,R,O> rFunction,
                                                       L rNewRightValue)
        Returns a new binary function that swaps the left and right parameters of another binary function. This allows to use such functions as unary functions with a fixed left parameter instead of the right parameter without the need for a re-implementation.
        Parameters:
        rFunction - The original binary function
        rNewRightValue - The right value of the new binary function with the datatype of the left parameter of the original function
        Returns:
        The new binary function

      • tryWith

        public static <I,R extends java.lang.AutoCloseable,O> Function<I,O> tryWith(ThrowingFunction<I,R> fOpenResource,
                                                                            ThrowingFunction<R,O> fProduceResult)
        Returns an unchecked function that evaluates a function in a try-with-resource code block with an AutoCloseable resource that is created by another functions.
        Parameters:
        fOpenResource - An unchecked function that opens a resource derived from the function input
        fProduceResult - An unchecked function that creates the function result from the resource
        Returns:
        A new unchecked function instance

      • unchecked

        public static <T> java.util.function.Consumer<T> unchecked(ThrowingConsumer<T> fChecked)
        Takes a consumer that throws an exception and returns it as a consumer that can be executed without a checked exception. This method is mainly intended to be used for lambdas that throw exceptions.
        Parameters:
        fChecked - The checked function to wrap as unchecked
        Returns:
        The unchecked function

      • unchecked

        public static <T> java.util.function.Supplier<T> unchecked(ThrowingSupplier<T> fChecked)
        Takes a supplier that throws an exception and returns it as a supplier that can be executed without a checked exception. This method is mainly intended to be used for lambdas that throw exceptions.
        Parameters:
        fChecked - The checked function to wrap as unchecked
        Returns:
        The unchecked function

      • unchecked

        public static <I,O> Function<I,O> unchecked(ThrowingFunction<I,O> fChecked)
        Takes a function that throws an exception and returns it as a function that can be executed without a checked exception. This method is mainly intended to be used for lambdas that throw exceptions.
        Parameters:
        fChecked - The checked function to wrap as unchecked
        Returns:
        The unchecked function

      • unixTimestamp

        public static <T> Function<T,java.lang.Integer> unixTimestamp()
        Returns a function that returns the current system time in the UNIX time format (i.e. seconds since January 1, 1970). This is the same value as the result of System.currentTimeMillis() divided by 1000.
        Returns:
        A function constant that returns the current UNIX timestamp

      • value

        public static <I,O> Function<I,O> value(O rValue)
        Returns a new function instance that always returns a certain value. The input value will always be ignored but is identified by the generic type I so that a specific type can be inferred when assigning the returned function to a typed variable.
        Parameters:
        rValue - The value to be returned by the function
        Returns:
        A new function instance

      • yield

        public static <T> Function<T,T> yield()
        Returns a function that invokes Thread.yield(). The input value of the function will be returned unchanged to allow function chaining.
        Returns:
        A function constant that causes the current thread to yield execution to other threads
